column1: Saint-Dié-des-Vosges (French pronunciation: ​[sɛ̃ dje de voʒ]; German: Sankt Didel)
column2: commonly referred to as just Saint-Dié
column3: is a commune in the Vosges department in Grand Est in northeastern France.

column1: It is a sub-prefecture of the department.
Saint-Dié is located in the Vosges Mountains 80 km (50 mi) southeast of Nancy and 45 km (28 mi) of Lunéville. This route in the valley of Meurthe was always the more frequented

column1: The town was nearly completely redesigned and rebuilt in the French Uniform Style after the fire of 1757. A major part was destroyed in November
column2: 1944 and was rebuilt largely in a material imitating red sandstone. Its cathedral has a Gothic nave and choir designed in the 14th century; the portal of red stone was created by Giovanni Betto in the beginning of the 18th century. A cloister

column1: Legends originating in the 11th century and popular traditions say Saint Dié dreamed of a new monastery in a little hill called "monticule des Jointures" in the other side of the river he could see. A little monastic community dedicated to saint Maurice

column1: The town was repeatedly sacked during the wars of the 15th
column2: 16th and 17th centuries. The little but religiously very prestigious town was partially destroyed by fire in 1554 and 1757. Funds for the rebuilding of the portion of the town destroyed by the last fire were supplied by Stanislas
column3: last duke of Lorraine.

column1: The diocese of Saint-Dié was created in 1777
column2: but suppressed by the Concordat of 1801. It was restored in 1822 as a suffragan of the Diocese of Besançon covering the department of the Vosges
column3: of which 18 parishes were transferred to the Diocese of Strasbourg in 1871.

column1: The diocese of Saint-Dié originated in the celebrated abbey
column2: initially named "Galilée"
column3: and was established by Saint Deodatus (Dié) in the 7th century
column4: around which the town of Saint-Dié grew up. The Benedictines of the original foundation Saint Maurice were replaced in 996 by Augustinian Canons.

column2: and the long vacancy of the see of Toul
column3: the abbots of the several monasteries in the Vosges
column4: without actually declaring themselves independent of the diocese of Toul
column5: claimed to exercise a quasi-episcopal jurisdiction. In 1718
column6: the Bishop of Toul requested the creation of a see at Saint-Dié
column7: but the suggestion was opposed by the King of France. The see was eventually created by Pope Pius VI in 1777 by the elevation of the abbey of Saint-Dié into a bishopric. The new diocese was removed from the diocese of Toul and made instead a suffragan of the German Archdiocese of Trier.

column2: Canon of St-Dié in charge of the mines of the valleys was the chaplain and secretary of René II
